history.text: Hello, I didn't watch the movie did you?
are you there?
Yes.  It was a good animated movie.  One kids would really like
Oh cool. I like anything animated. Is it a recent movie?

It seems even the critics think so as it got an A+ score from CinemaScore.  I wouldn't call 2013 'recent' unless you are also into really old movies.  They casted Kristen Bell as Anna, though I really liked how Jonathan Groff played Kristoff.
Oh haha, Frozen?
I didn't realize it was Disney's 53rd feature film.  Glad they based it off a good author like Hans Christian Anderson.  A good story to start with makes for a good movie.
Yup.
I've seen a bit of it, I never decided to watch it in its entirety.
Wow, 53 feature films!
I know, right?!  Wondering when it will become a musical on broadway.  Not that I am one to go see them, but it seems to be the progress of things.
I always wondered how different it would have turned out if they had not erased Anna's memories.  Poor Elsa, living with all that guilt.

Haha I wonder too, that would be nice. Like you said earlier it is popular with kids. I'm more of an old-school Disney fan. I think the last Disney movies I've actively watched and thoroughly enjoyed were Toy Story and Monsters inc. but I'll still watch things like Fox and the Found and want to cry like a baby haha
Elsa erased Anna's memories?
Hound*
How does she do that?

If it wasn't for my kids, I wouldn't have seen this either.  They were actually too young when it came out, weren't really into watching movies.  Then a friend showed them the movie and I didn't hear anything else for days afterwards.  Could have used some of those memory erasing skills the trolls had.  The trolls erased Anna's memories of her sister's magical abilities in order to save her life.

The trolls warned her not to use her magic or it might trigger Anna's memories to come back, thereby undoing what was done to keep her from freezing.  So, instead of mastering her snow/cold skills, Elsa hid them.  She came to see them as something horrible and wrong.
Hahaha that is cute about your kids. Ah, I see. So does Elsa eventually train herself or it ends before she can do that?

It didn't help matters any when the parents ended up dying at sea, leaving Elsa to enter adulthood without them there to support and guide her.  It really is a good story line, though obviously aimed at kids.
Sounds enjoyable too from a fiction-lover's perspective. Anything with spells and stuff like that is pretty great to me.
Well, when she came up age at 21, she had not yet mastered the skill and the citizens of her kingdom didn't know about it.

She continues to try and hid it, meanwhile Anna can't figure out what she did wrong to make her sister suddenly stop wanting to play with her, to make her (Elsa) so up tight.  Then come in the standard guy - handsome, saves the day.  but then yet another twist - turns out his only goal is to marry Elsa so he can kill her and take over the kingdom.
oh no ):
My bad, I meant, he was looking to marry Anna, though he did want to take over the kingdom.
that's horrible I hope she doesn't marry him
Do you think this movie is better than Wreck-It Ralph? I just remembered I liked that Disney movie and I think they came out the same year or around the same year not sure.

Well .... :)  Elsa and Anna have an argument over something, Elsa releases her powers in a moment of anger, sees what she has done, and flees to the mountains thinking everyone will think she is a monster.  What she doesn't realize is that she has now created an eternal winter over the kingdom.
hmm.  I think it depends on what you are going for.  I liked the ending to Wreck it Ralph better.  Frozen ended with an untraditional scene, the love between sisters saving the day.
As a movie for kids, I think they will have enough years ahead of them for romantic movies, I like to see ones which encourage friendships and helping others.
Yea definitely. Love Disney for their messages, always have.
Kids don't look that in depth into their behavior unless they're entertained by cutesy sing along stuff

The speed of the newer Disney movies seems to be faster than that of the older ones, even Fox and Hound.  In that, I think the newer ones are not necessarily better as they do not give time for the viewers to solve things on their own or consider what might happen.
exactly
at least kids nowadays
i dunno interesting thought haha cause and effect maybe?
Disney movies when we were kids weren't as stimulating
but they definitely made us feel something
still
I hope Disney doesn't want to dumb our kids down, because they definitely know how to grab their attention. You never know in this world today.
Definantly different animation. The in this movie were more realistic than say, oh, what is the one with Mickey Mouse and the magician and the dancing brooms.
Yea definitely more attention to every little detail etc

That is one thing I did like about this movie, when you thought you had figured out who was going to give "true love's kiss" to save Anna (i.e. the guy), it turns out it came from her sister.  It really did make even me stop and think about assumptions.
That love is not a shallow feeling, but something deeper.  It may have been lost on the kids though.  I know my son did appreciate that there were no kissing scenes.

That's great actually! I remember as a kid my younger sister loved watching Pocahontas and singing to it all the time, and I as a brother put up with it because I was a pretty nice brother, so maybe its like that.
Haha I tend to make a lot of assumptions about movies. I wasn't even born in the 80s but I appreciate things from 80s-2000 a lot more than anything after.
If you were looking for something to watch with some younger kids, or perhaps something no too heavy yet no shallow, it wouldn't be a bad choice.  There were several comical scenes.
Yea. I mean at some point I'll probably watch it. I watched Tangled in its entirety for some reason.

Particularly, I like Kristoff.  Perhaps it is because he is the outdoorsy type, made me miss being out in the woods.  Had absolutely nothing to do with the movie, though is character is hard not to like.
LOL  okay, I think it is better than Tangled.
Nice
Did you see Happy Feet?
I don't think that was Disney, but I liked it.
I did.  Loved it, till the end.  I may be a lover of nature but did not appreciate the in-your-face environmentalism added, didn't seem to fit.
Oh yeah..
they tanked the ending
like how sausage party tanked their ending don't know if you saw that
No, didn't see that one.
Don't! Haha unless you are willing to be distracted from normal thoughts for a couple days.
It just made me walk around shaking my head wondering what I watched until I could block it out
I will take your word for it.
Thanks for the heads up.
Haha :P for sure
anyways don't know if you noticed but you can click finish convo at the end
it was nice talking to you, thanks for conversation
definitely was interesting
You too, have a great evening.
you too thanks!!

uid1response.feedback: The conversation went smoothly once we found common ground to converse on and it was not just me recanting the story or summarizing what I was reading.  In the end, it was a good conversation, though we stayed on the topic of movies we did deviate a bit to include our previous histories with other movies, which helped make it a richer conversation.

uid2response.feedback: Person made some interesting points and convinced me I should see it! This was fun, but next time alert us when convo is over, that would have went on forever if I didn't notice!!
